I found a mistake during construction of DinamicNavigationMesh in a scene loaded objects containing CrowdAgent component. DinamicNavigationMesh builds incorrect navigational grid for objects containing CrowdAgent component.
Who knows the solution to this problem?

Best regards,

data.title: UIElement::GetCombinedScreenRect is not recursive
Added a check before deleting stuff in hashmap
data.body:
When a hashmap is being declared and initialized (```m_map()``` in constructor), but not actually used in any way, an NPE will be thrown when closing the app.

This is due to the last line in the destructor, ```delete[] ptrs_;```, which deletes a NULL variable.

Since all other calls inside the destructor are relaying on some data to exists,
and we're checking ptrs_ anyway (assuming the PR is good, that is), there's no reason
not to wrap the other calls as well; At least IMO, correct me if I'm wrong.

data.title: Failed to lock index buffer when using intents on Android
data.body: I have simple java function that opens a file using intents on Android under Urho3D. When I close the intent window Urho3D starts to print Failed to lock index buffer. At the moment the intent function is part of the Urho3D activity.

data.title: Bug of DecalSet found at Samples:08_Decals
data.body:
Build on:
 - Urho3D-1.6
 - Windows10
 - vs2015 x64
 - use c++11

I found this problem when I learn from Samples:08_Decals. After put too many decals on one Node, it showed a surprised phenomenon: When I added a new decal, the initial one disappeared. That would happened after adding about 125 decals to **one Node**. See these pictures. 


![bug_decalsets](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20684730/20142000/ed152756-a6cd-11e6-97c6-58a41fe470e0.gif)


![bug_decalsets1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20684730/20142224/da7e8276-a6ce-11e6-9578-4c7f05d41048.gif)

data.title: Android release and sign problem
data.body:
Hi guys, I am trying to release the ninja demo on android with urho3d-1.6, but it keep crushing when I run it on my android devices.

I just followed the build guide:
1. android update project  -p . - t 1
2. make -j8
3. ant release
4. signed & verify my sign
5. run and crush without any message.

However, If I use "ant debug" in the 3rd step, I can get everything well. but I am trying to release an apk.

I have try the older version of Urho3D (the version around 2015 December), both debug and release are OK.

How can I find out the problem? any help?

data.title: Incorrect normal mapping on billboards
data.body:
How to reproduce:
- Create Directional light
- Create BillboardSet with some billboards
- Apply any material with normals to it, e.g. Data/Materials/StoneSmall.xml
- Look at the BillboardSet from various angles. Sometimes it is lit correctly, sometimes it becomes black, sometimes normals become flipped or distorted.
Maybe the issue is somehow related to tangent coords of billboards?

data.title: Added namespace prefix for various calls to GetVariantType
data.body:
Various calls to GetVariantType are missing a using namespace.

As such, when a project doesn't have the line ```using namespace Urho3D``` (such as my own ^^), a compile error will be generated regarding the use of GetVariantType.

This fixes that.

data.title: [FindDirectX.cmake] execute_process output_file needs to be absolute
data.body:
I'm trying to build Urho3D from source with cmake and mingw,
and I've encountered an error running cmake. The following line:

https://github.com/urho3d/Urho3D/blob/master/CMake/Modules/FindDirectX.cmake#L78

Results in an error, since the file doesn't seems to exists in the expected directory.
I've solved it by simply editing the output_file path to an absolute one, using same variable.

```
execute_process (COMMAND ${CMAKE_COMMAND} -E echo "#include <_mingw.h>" COMMAND ${CMAKE_C_COMPILER} -E -M - OUTPUT_FILE ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/find_mingw_sysroot_output)
```

As you can see, the original cmake code at line 77 doesn't contains ```${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}```, and from some reason it causes issues. I also see no reason to use absolute paths either, specially since it's being used a second later to read from that file anyway.

data.title: Area lighting and Quality improvements to IBL
data.body:
This commit includes the following:

-Sphere Area Lighting
-Tube Area Lighting
-Mip selection based on epics approach for higher quality
-Physically accurate attenuation
-Improve Cubemap seams on d3d9 and opengl, as mentioned in #1646 
-Update scene to demonstrate area lighting
-Re-import all textures to fix normal map artifacts

data.title: Added SetDrawRect and SetTextureRect in StaticSprite2D
data.body: This PR adds function to override the draw and texture rectangles of a StaticSprite2D

data.title: Forward lighting command override existed render target
data.body:
I use two pass rending, the first pass is to make a QUAT, the second pass is to render the original effect, then combine them together.

Here is the render path:
```
<renderpath>
    <rendertarget name="blurv" tag="Bloom" sizedivisor="4 4" format="rgb" filter="true" />
    <rendertarget name="blurh" tag="Bloom" sizedivisor="4 4" format="rgb" filter="true" />

    <command type="clear" color="fog" depth="1.0" stencil="0" output="viewport" />
    <command type="scenepass" pass="base2" vertexlights="true" metadata="base" output="viewport" />
    <command type="forwardlights" pass="light2" output="viewport" />

    <command type="quad" tag="Bloom" vs="Bloom" ps="Bloom" psdefines="BRIGHT" output="blurb">
        <parameter name="BloomThreshold" value="0.0" />
        <texture unit="diffuse" name="viewport" />
    </command>
    <command type="quad" tag="Bloom" vs="Bloom" ps="Bloom" psdefines="BLURH" output="blush">
        <texture unit="diffuse" name="blurv" />
    </command>
    <command type="quad" tag="Bloom" vs="Bloom" ps="Bloom" psdefines="BLURV" output="blurb">
        <texture unit="diffuse" name="blurh" />
    </command>

    <command type="clear" color="fog" depth="1.0" stencil="0" output="viewport" />
    <command type="scenepass" pass="base" vertexlights="true" metadata="base" output="viewport" />

    <!--
    <command type="forwardlights" pass="light" output="viewport" />
     -->

    <command type="quad" tag="Bloom" vs="Bloom" ps="Bloom" psdefines="COMBINE" output="viewport">
        <parameter name="BloomMix" value="1.0 1.0" />
        <texture unit="diffuse" name="viewport" />
        <texture unit="normal" name="blurv" />
    </command>
</renderpath>
```

If I uncomment the second 'forwardlights' command, the render target of 'blurv' will be override, its content will change.

data.title: Soft particles renderpaths. Is it a good design decision?
data.body:
I have believed that renderpaths are intended for more "fundamental" things like forward/deferred rendering but not for implementing of particular graphical effects. If you implement an another feature in the same way (snow rendering, for example), will you have ForwardSnow.xml, ForwardSPSnow.xml, DeferredSPSnow.xml, etc? 
It will turn the renderpath into a god object.

I don't see reason why soft particles can't be implemented as a technique and work with existing renderpaths (ForwardDepth, Deferred). This renderpaths provide the depth texture and the soft particles shader can read it (like the water shader reads the color texture now).

data.title: Optimize Editor work with temporary objects
data.body:
Related to #1664 
I'ven't managed to fix bottleneck in Hierarchy View. However, I've optimized temorary nodes and how Editor deal with them. Since procedural nodes like terrain pathces are temporary, these changes are pretty good workaround for my issue.
Please, review changes in **EditorHierarchyWindow.as** for possible unwanted side effects.

data.title: minor typo fixes
data.body: A majority are completely trivial.

data.title: HiresTick()   wrong behaviour on Windows
Add `KEY_UNKNOWN` to `InputEvents.h`.
Add vertex colors to standart primitives
Bottleneck in hierarchy ListView
data.body:
I've noticed that adding new nodes in Editor costs much more than I expected.
E.g. when I have several thousands of nodes, adding new node takes about 15ms and this time grows with scene complexity. This is quite important for procedurally spawned nodes (even temporary), because spawning several hundreds of nodes take more than second.
The biggest part of time is spent inside _nodeadded_ event.
I suppose it is caused by rebuilding and reallocating of items list even if hierarchy is hidden or collapsed.
I am trying to somehow optimise it... E.g. create tree data structure instead of plain vector inside HierarchyContainer. Or maybe just disable all these updates if hierarchy is hidden.
Does anybody have good ideas?

data.title: Don't save line repetitions in the console's history
data.body: Not saving repetitive lines since it's redundant and makes it longer to navigate to not-the-same previous lines.

data.title: Upgrade to SDL v2.0.5
Add an emplace back method to the vector class when C++11 is enabled.
data.body: However, following the style of C++17 by returning a reference to the created instance.
